At-a-Glance: The Snelgrove method manipulates bee movement using a division board with closable entrances, bleeding young bees down to the queen while allowing brood above to emerge. It curbs swarming without losing foraging strength.
Why it Matters: Compared with simple splits, Snelgrove keeps field force and honey production higher through the main flow while diffusing swarm impulse.
Step-by-Step: Find and leave the queen with eggs/young brood below. Place the Snelgrove board and brood above with queen cells broken down except one if increase is desired. Open and close specific board entrances over a 7â€“10 day schedule to redistribute flyers. Re-inspect to manage cells and space.
Seasonality & Climate: Apply during spring build-up before swarming peaks. Adjust entrance timings for local weather and flows.
Common Pitfalls: Losing track of which entrances are open; leaving multiple queen cells; failing to provide adequate space above/below.
Tools & Materials: Snelgrove board with gates, queen excluder if required, spare frames/supers, and a clear day-by-day plan.
